repnme.cdata!:
Africa - Togo/Benin Engineering and
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the project were
            inconsistent with its expected outputs. It was not realistic
            to expect that a project, which basically included
            feasibility and tariff studies, would have an impact on
            sector efficiency and long-term cost of electricity supply
            without any follow-up investment. The project was prepared
            during a period of political turmoil in Togo. It was
            designed to give the joint power and transmission company
            (CEB) and the World Bank an instrument to prepare the ground
            for future investment after the return to normalcy in Togo.
            Although it was an apt instrument given the circumstances,
            it could not deliver more than what it was designed to
            achieve. Project objective benefit has to be assessed in the
            narrow context of CEB's operations, as well as in the
            broader context of the two power rehabilitation projects
            implemented simultaneously in Benin and Togo. In the narrow
            context, the project outputs are rated as satisfactory given
            that the project had a substantial impact on institutional
            development. The studies carried out with the active
            participation of CEB staff gave them an opportunity to
            review the merits of options for supplying power to the
            Benin\Togo system, and to deepen their understanding of
            tariff issues. Since institutional development achieved with
            project assistance is expected to be a lasting improvement,
            project sustainability is likely. Bank performance is rated
            satisfactory despite the disconnect between project
            objectives and components.

repnme.cdata!:
Togo - Engineering and Technical Assistance
            Project - Benin

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's main objectives are
            to:  (a) improve sector efficiency and minimize the
            long-term cost of electricity supply in Benin and Togo; (b)
            strengthen the Communaute Electrique du Benin's
            (CEB's) management and operations through technical
            assistance and training; and (c) encourage regional
            cooperation and integration.  The project emphasizes
            technical assistance and training for institutional
            strengthening and regional development, as reflected in the
            following components: (a) updating of the countries'
            least-cost generation, transmission and distribution master
            plans; (b) evaluation of CEB's short-term supply
            requirements, including a review of existing thermal plants,
            and definition of a model for regional power interchange;
            (c) detailed engineering and bidding documents of the
            northern interconnections; (d) the design of standard models
            for substations, towers and conductors for the 161 kV system
            expansion; (e) tariff studies for CEB, the Societe Beninoise
            d'Electricite et d'Eau and the Compagnie Energie
            Electrique du Togo, including an analysis of long run
            marginal costs as a guide to tariff structure and of revenue
            requirements to set the rates; (f) updating supply options,
            including hydroelectric schemes, international
            interconnections and environmental assessment; and (g)
            institutional strengthening of CEB, including training,
            legal, planning and computerization.
